awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Applications of Quantum Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum information is the study of what quantum mechanics means as a theory of information.  Striking, but still incompletely understood, features of the theory include the uncertainty principle, entanglement, quantum cryptography and quantum computing.  

The first part of the proposed research will tackle core questions in quantum information theory that have been barriers to its wider applicability.  For example: to what extent can the "monogamy" (or non-shareability) of quantum entanglement be used to distinguish it from classical correlation?  What does it mean for information in a system to be contained in its short-range or long-range degrees of freedom?

The second part of this research will extend the reach of quantum information theory by developing applications in condensed-matter physics, optimization algorithms and other areas of math and physics.  Through progress on the core problems above, this research hopes to develop better simulations of quantum systems, better understanding of how entanglement functions in many-body physics and new algorithms for hard optimization problems.  These tools are expected to be of use not only to researchers in quantum information, but to a wide range of physicists and computer scientists.  

This research will be done together with a graduate student, who will learn techniques from physics, computer science and mathematics.  Additionally, related topics will be integrated into undergraduate teaching.

por.por_cntn:
In quantum entanglement, the state of a collection of small systems cannot be described simply by describing the state of each individual system.  This is like describing correlations in random systems but entanglement can be present even when the state of the overall system is perfectly known.  This phenomenon of entanglement is behind the exponentially faster performance of quantum computers for some tasks, but at the same time, makes it exponentially difficult for our current computers to simulate quantum systems such as molecules and subatomic particles.
This project found many ways of using the tools of quantum information to better understand many-body physics, and of using tools from quantum physics to advance our understanding of computing. A key principle has been a different way of understanding entanglement.  When we move to systems with more than two components (such as a molecule made of many atoms), it is often challenging to clearly describe entanglement: do we mean entanglement between individual subsystems, or collections of subsystems, or multipartite entanglement that cannot be described in terms of two-body correlations?  Our approach has been to look for conditional independence: given regions ABC, we say taht A and C are conditionally independent given B if the system has AB entangelment and BC entanglement but no AC entanglement.  A similar situation arises in probability theory, where we look for random variables that influence each other only indirectly via a third variable.
Our research advanced basic theory questions about quantum conditional independence, such as the properties of quantum systems that approximately satisfy this property. It also connected this to several applications.  One such application was developing new simulation algorithms for conventional computers to calculate the properties of quantum systems.  This is relevant to current discussions of "quantum supremacy," which is the goal of having quantum computers solve some benchmark problem faster than any possible classical computer; by improving the simulations that classical computers can do, we show that quantum computers have to work harder to surpass them.  Another application is to understanding the power of computer proof systems.  These often succeed when variables can be broken into conditionally independent pieces and fail when they cannot be.  Surprisingly, these algorithms can be fruitfully described in terms of quantum states, even when they are run on classical computers.  We were able to advance our knowledge of both the power and limitations of these algorithms by using techniques from quantum information.
This project also trained several graduate and undergraduate students in these topics, most of whom have continued research careers in academia or industry. The PI involved develoepd several new courses including a graduate course at the intersection of quantum information and mnay-body physics (with publicly available materials), and an EdX class on quantum computing; as well as incorporating quantum information content into the standard quantum mechanics classes taken by MIT Physics undergrads.
